You have fun going out on dates with I'll. The pace of life is relaxed, and you find yourself taking things a bit less seriously than you otherwise might.
One evening, she approaches you about your financial future.
You talk to your father and they agree to meet up between the castle and the village hall for a late lunch.

you've reached the end of this arc. Like a hero, you must now decide how to proceed.
Yes.
Go to the next part of the story.
No.
End the story here.

Adventure contest.

"Argh!" The Evil Wizard exclaims as you thrust your long sword into his shoulder.
"Your streak of evil is over, Lord Waouiji! Surrender or fall to my blade!" You say heroically as you draw the sword from the evil lord's shoulder.
> Boxot says "For some reason I'm imagining the antagonist looking and sounding like Waluigi"
"Waaahh!" Lord Waluigi heavily stumbles backwards  eventually crashing into a shelf stocked to its limits with various potions with a wide variety of sizes and colors.
A particularly small black vial falls from the shelf and lands in front of the Dark Lord.
Waouiji quickly grabs the bottle and uncorks it. "Don't do it!" you shout, but

Waouji enthusiastically exclaims in a triumph tone, "Too late you pesky adventurer! Once I consume this potion, it is I who shall be Victorious! Wah ha ha!" And with that, Lord Wauiji quickly chugs down the mysterious dark cacaucation.
For a heartbeat, nothing happens. Then Lord Waouiji begins to transform.
> CodySir says "This is turning out good so far!"
The air in the underground secret underground laboratory begins to become thick with the evil energy that is now radiating from Lord Wauigi!
> Boxot says "It really is, never done something like this before! Very fun"
The Dark Lord's hair begins to lengthen and turn a stark white as the clouds of darkness consume him.
His thighs begin the increase in size and his...chest begins expanding!?
> CodySir says "We're doing a semi-detailed transformation sequence?"
> Boxot shrugs.
> CodySir says "Okay"
> CodySir says "Anime transformation sequence, go!"
You can still make out Lord Waouiji's transformation through the crackling smoke, and it's...odd.

Not only is his figure gaining a bust, but he's also shrinking too.

(Insert Transformation sequence and/or smoke here)
After the smoke finally settles you notice that not only has the Dark lord transformed into an Anime school girl with bunny ears but all of his physical prowess has seemingly increased ten fold!
"W-what-?" Before you can form a sentence,

You're launched into a wall by a powerful kick by the newly transformed Lord Wauiji into a wall causing a large crater!

"Wah ha ha! Prepare for your inevitable defeat adventurer! Wah ha...why do I feel so damn bubbly of a sudden!?"

Both sides having a slight respect for how far they must've come and fire in their eyes; truly, this would be a fight for the ages as they draw their weapons with determination' 'and then what happened?' 'Oh, the dark lord just lost his memory at that moment and just stopped taking over the world' '...How did you get in my house anyway?'"
> CodySir says "Pretty much. The exchange went something like this...'

"Because you drank a friggin potion that's why!" You sputter angrily, still trying to get out of the hole in the wall.

"I drank a potion? O-oh dear!"
"You don't remember, like two seconds ago? There was an elaborate transformation sequence and everything! "

You raise your sword toward the bunny girl, looking to see if the Dark Lord is still behind those eyes.
"You drank a potion." You say, pointing out the obvious.
"Hmm, maybe that explains why I feel so frisky!" The bunny eared schoolgirl thinks aloud with a beaming smile.
 "Does the name Lord Waouiji ring any bells?" you ask.
"Waouiji? Wasn't that the Dark Lord my father was talking about?" The transformed girl asks.

You lower your sword. Somehow, Lord Waouiji transformed himself into a bunny monster schoolgirl with no memory of being a dark lord before the transformation. It's like he got amnesia or something.
"Ah, I see." You say.
"So...what now that you know my true identity?" The transformed Lord Waouji asks with a pout.

You say "Well...Um...Let's just say you were an evil, ugly dark wizard. You drank a potion and now..."
"What? What is it?"
"You're now a cute bunny eared schoolgirl." You blurt out.
"I'm a what!?"
Before the dark lord could demand answers, you quickly begin to back away...
"Wait!" Lord Waouji shouts as she grabs your wrist!

You stand your ground, looking into the eyes of the dark lord. You see through his eyes...or is it her eyes. Either way, you see nothing but your reflection in his eyes. He doesn't recognize you.

My Hero is the one that gave me the idea considering Deku even then is a quick planner; having a good amount of knowledge in Heroes and Villains alike...but then BAM! superpowers. I love My Hero overall, but seeing this really shows a big issue; the concept of a powerless superhero is STILL up for grabs!"

It's characters like that and Mumen Rider that need that representation to be an inspiration to time and even Marvel, for as relatable as it manages to be, can't have that same relatability in the road to be a hero. Similar to the real superheroes that do what they can to help others in a costume. Something like that, I feel, could be breakthrough in giving the concept of superheroes be truly respected in the mainstream."

> cw_obliuette says "...which is why I don't like the concept of pushing the relatability a superhero in general, which is also why I don't like the superhero genre that much when it comes to DC and Marvel."

> cw_obliuette says "Live action can and will give an interesting narrative, but only if you nail it correctly. For someone like me, Marvel and DC can pull out all the stops, make a character be as relatable and realistic as ‘movie magic' can, have them as three-dimensional as the "here comes the sun" video from bill wurtz, but the moment I also know that they are from some random planet with power, then POW, I cannot then, in good conscious, enjoy a movie under a false pretense of it being relatable when a character is abnormal, inhuman, or otherwise paracasually different."

> cw_obliuette says "My brain cannot wrap around that idea, which is why I prefer animation to live action. You already know then that it's not real, and for someone like me, it fits better. Though, I find it ironic that I can't handle live action but can handle animation, of the same characters of the same studio and genre."

> Solskinns says "I'm actually the same way, there's only so much you can do in live action because it's all the more real life. Oh cool you know that video too though I'm sure a lot of people saw that with enthusiasm of his return. It's probably why DC has progressed animation-wise and the live action TV more or less embraces the silliness of it, it's not relatable at ALL, but it's entertaining and sometimes engaging."

title: The Scarecrow And The Rouge
memory:
[You are Ricky, a male.

You know everything about Erleggon, from politics to dungeon locations. Erleggon is a fantasy world of your own design that your soul got transferred into.
You are able to use Fire magic proficiently, and you know a little of Ice magic.
You have on you, a small backpack, a wooden sword, a silver dagger, and a gold iphone.
You wear a leather armor.]

[There are many species that inhabit Erleggon, such as humans, monster girls/boys, elves, orcs, and dragons.

There used to be no hostile monsters and undead in Erleggon. Now, because of the Fragment, there is no city that is not threatened by evil.]

[Your current quest is to go to the Nivellian village of Truce Mill, and rescue their hero, who has been kidnapped by the evil wizard Gigant.]

[A sarecrow is following you and commenting all your actions.
He reffers at you as 'the player']

[You are inside of the Gigant's castle looking for the kidnapped hero]
authorsNote: This is a fantasy adventure. The player knows most things about the world, from politics to dungeon locations.

worldInfo.entry: Erleggon is the collective name for the world. It is inhabited by many humanoid species, such as humans themselves, monster girls/boys, elves, dwarves, and orcs. It is slowly being consumed by the Fragment, which destroys the land and creates monstrous creatures.
The Fragment is a void-like phenomena that nobody can explain. It slowly spreads across erleggon, creating an oceanic abyss that evil creatures pour out of.

Humans are one of the smaller populations of Erleggon, but their numbers are growing fast. Half of the kingdoms haves human rulers, making them the moast influential species. Humans are most skilled at diplomacy and fine arts, with most dabbling in fanciful pursuits like poetry, theater, or jousting. In fact, humans are considered to be the best horse riders and tamers in all the land.

Forest Elves are the most secretive of all races. Ever since their kingdom got taken by the Shadow Elves of Cradletide, most either went into hiding or fled the old Elven kingdom. In some Human-dominated areas of Erleggon, Forest Elves are more numerous that the humans themselves. Forest Elves are characterized by their treebark-like skin tone and notoriously long and sensitive ears. Forest Elves are the best archers in Erleggon.

Shadow Elves used to rule Erleggon with an empire. However, internal strife took hold of the empire and wrung it dry, resulting in the creation of the 6 kingdoms. The Shadow Elves went back to their homeland of Cradletide, and eventually came back to Erleggon in force to stage a successful coup in the Elven Kingdom, and very little still live in Cradletide or any other kingdoms in Erleggon. Shadow Elves are masters of the dark arts, and are characterized by their ashy grey skin and sharp ears.

Kitsunes are humanoids characterized by their foxlike ears and tails, of which there can be only 1 or up to 9. The amount of tails a kitsune has signifies their status, 1 being a lowly serf or adventurer and 9 being a ruler. Kitsunes are masters of Fire elemental magic, and can call on their Fox-Fire to unleash devastating pyromantic carnage.

Feli are humnoids characterized by their cat-like ears and tail, along with their often miscievious personalities. They are masters of trading, and many of Erleggob's biggest companies and guilds are controlled by Feli. A felus assassin can be ruthless and unstoppably deadly due to Feli agility and dexterity.

Lupines are humanoids with wolf-like ears and tails. They are an extremely proud folk and many consider their suicidal sense of honor either inspiring or insane. They are the quickest minds on the battlefield, and many famous commanders are Vulpines. In fact, it was a Vulpine who united the various humanoid species under one banner.

Ursi are humanoids with round, bear-like ears and short puffy tails. Many would call them a callous people, but in reality Ursi are the most protective and caring species towards people who are important to them. Put a two-handed weapon in the two hands of an Ursus, and they will wreak bloody havoc on their enemies while subsequently refusing to succumb to any wounds.

Angoras are humanoids with long rabbitlike ears and fluffy circular tails. They are known to be the most romantic and lusty of the races, and are naturally energetic and playful. Angoras are great at harassing enemies with their superior speed and endurance, chipping away at an enemy's life force while avoiding damage altogether.

Dwarves are the master craftsmen of Erleggon, and are widely praised for their works. They gave up kingdom managing a long time ago to get rich off of their skill at making arms and armor for levies and nobles alike. They are a stout people, and some have beards reaching down all the way to their feet.

The Orcs are considered to be a cruel race of unrefined savages. They live in semi-nomadic tribal groups that sometimes go down south to pillage the northern kingdoms. Orcs who migrate down to Erleggon without the intent to raid are the best mercenaries gold can buy, and their mere presence can intimidate the enemy and shift the tide of battle.

The Undead are the nickname for the evil creatures that spew out of the Fragment, as it is confirmed that those who die to the Fragment are turned into undead. They take on many forms and sizes, and some evem retain the skills they had before dying, making them a diverse and tough enemy to fight without an army.

Giants are a race of massive humanoids who terrorize farmers and travellers alike for food and for fun. It is said that Giants are the primitive ancestors of Humans and Orcs, and they live in hunter-gatherer societies. They cannot speak the languages of Erleggon, instead using an ancient tongue found on century-old carvings and scrolls.

Dragons are the most feared race in Erleggon, and have caused countless disasters and genocides. They are massive, terrifying lizards with the ability to take to the skies and rain fire from above, making them practically unkillable without the help of magic used for the specific purpose of killing the beasts.

worldInfo.keys: the kingdom of mercia,kingdom of mercia,mercia
worldInfo.entry: The Kingdom of Mercia is a human-ruled kingdom that is fanatically religious. They have launched many crusades against kingdoms who do not follow the Mercian religion as well as the Orcs of the north, often resulting in nothing gained for either side. Executions for sinning in the eyes of the church are widespread, and Mercia is the only place where the Human population is declining.

King John is a callous, uncaring ruler who wants to keep the balance of power in Erleggon stable, mostly so he can keep launching unsuccessful crusades. He instates harsh taxes and tariffs to keep his people weak, but desperate enough to work. He uses much of the money to bribe his nobles so they don't rebel against him again.

Lucifer Dungeon is one of the 10 dungeons in the world. It is the biggest one, and completing an expedition into it would take days and smart provisioning. The monsters that inhabit it are demonic in nature, and they frequently use fire against dungeon crawlers.

The Middle Kingdom was formed by disgruntled Mercian nobles after a successful rebellion to secede from Mercia and the King's brutal taxes and wasteful military efforts. The middle kingdom often clashes with the Kingdom of Ruga to its south, but is otherwise peaceful and the go-to place for adventurers to start their journeys. It is also home to the neutral city of New Hope, which it protects, trades with, and funds.

worldInfo.keys: king graveth,king of the middle kingdom
worldInfo.entry: King Graveth is a just ruler who puts law and order above all else. In Mercian fashion, he provides brutal punishments to lawbreakers, but his laws are fair and equal for all.

Ravenstone dungeon is an aquatic dungeon located in the Middle Kingdom that hosts all kinds of grotesque and vile fish corrupted by the Fragment. If one wishes to venture into ravenstone, they must brace themselves for ruthless peircing attacks that will slowly kill them from blood loss.

worldInfo.keys: the kingdom of ruga,kingdom of ruga,ruga
worldInfo.entry: The kingdom of Ruga is a very prosperous nation with a booming economy and disciplined army. However, the native Rugese are extremely intolerant towards the non-human races, even the monster girls and monster boys. This means that very few of the people who live in Ruga aren't pure Human, and those that do are living in hiding and fear.

King Meija is as average as kings go - average taxes, average tariffs, and the average aggressive diplomacy of a medieval king. He doesn't see any problems with his kingdom, do he doesn't try to fix anything. His kingdom's protracted war with the Middle Kingdom is partly to blame for this attitude.

The war between Ruga and the Middle kingdom seems to be trapped in a constant stalemate. The Rugese army is superior to that of the Middle Kingdom, but the men of the Middle Kingdon are experienced veterans who fight harder and to the last. The Middle Kingdom also has many Orcish mercenary companies hired, something that Ruga refuses to do because of their intolerance towards other races.

Dankmire Dungeon is filled with angry reptilian creatures who can poison and sting, slowly draining an adventurer's life force. Even those who make it out alive are left with deadly and sometimes incurable diseases that need to be treated quickly.

The Elven Kingdom, originally named the kingdom of Tal'thur, is a hotbed of internal strife and political intrigue. It used to be ruled by the Forest Elves, but after the Shadow Elves came down from Cradletide to reclaim the heart of their former empire, it has been under oppressive Shadow Elf rule, and is locked in a bloody struggle between Shadow and Forest elves for what is, de jure, the Forest Elves homeland.

High King Tal is a scheming, clever king bent on using diplomacy and intrigue to slowly reform the great Empire that the Shadow Elves once ruled. He left the Shadow Elf homeland and staged a coup in the Forest Elves homeland to gain power for himself, and he has spies in every court in Erleggon.

Shardfall Dungeon is located in the Kingdom of Elves is packed tight with traps and machines that can kill an unwary adventurer instantly... or slowly and gruesomely. There are also many dark mages wielding all sorts of destructive spells that can weaken or hurt.

the Kingdom of Alachia, ruled by the naïve Queen Johana, is a very loose and disorganized nation of mostly autonomous Boyars that only answer to the Queen's orders, and not her laws. The Appalacians are usually too busy waging clan wars against each other, and their lands are poor in resources, so they are greatly disconnected with the outside world. The Katarmid Kingdom sees them as a useful buffer against northern raiders, however, and supplies them with gold and arms to keep it centralized.

Queen Johana is a pure-hearted queen who only wants to see her people united and her kingdom relevant among the other nations. The greedy and discordant Boyars constantly halt her efforts and she struggles to maintain control of her own position as queen, as the Boyars vie for power and leverage over one another.

worldInfo.keys: alachian wheat crisis,alachian crisis,alachian wheat famine,alachian famine
worldInfo.entry: Ever since the Fragment appeared and completely toppled the once filthy rich Katarmid Kingdom, the Alachians have been recieving less and less funds from the outside. The constant internal warring that they wage disrupts crop growth and allows monsters from the Fragment to let Hell loose around the countryside, resulting in a terrible famine that is starving thousands of Alachians.

Snowclaw dungeon is carved into the side of the largest mountain in Alachia, which is the only place in Alachia that actually has snow. Ancient warriors of great renown are buried here, brought back to life as powerful vessels of evil by the Fragment. The humanoid monsters of this dungeon are the strongest that an Adventurer will ever face.

The Katarmid Empire is an extremely diverse nation founded when Henry Katar united the Humanoid races of the southwest Erleggon under one flag. They enjoyed prosperity and influence, becoming an important trading partner to the other Erleggon kingdoms. The Fragment hit the Katarmids the hardest, however, and turned their once mighty empire into a backwater. Many migrated outside of the Empire, and monster girls and boys are present in number throughout all of Erleggon.

Imperator Lucius, the emperor of the Katarmids, is struggling to keep his Empire afloat. It is on the brink of collapse, and he promises his people acres of land to combat the mass desertions, which angers his nobles.

Fatami Dungeon is located in the Katarmid Empire, and contains endless hordes of weak, cannon fodder enemies. One will need to be well suited to crowd control to be able to sucessfully venture into this dungeon.

worldInfo.keys: new hope,the neutral city of new hope
worldInfo.entry: New Hope is a neutral city that lies between the border of the Middle Kingdom and Alachia. It is funded and protected by the Middle Kingdom, and is the perfect place for Adventurers to get some respite after arduous expeditions.
Darkwood Dungeon is a relatively safe dungeon situated near New Hope. It has little in the way of loot, but has many low-level monsters for newbie adventurers to train themselves with.

The Fragmented Lands is the term for the land west of Erleggon that has been completely consumed by the fragment. Only the most skilled adventurers make it out alive, as unspeakable horrors will come at you with every step you take. A high-level fortifying spell is required to even step foot into the Fragment without being consumed by the void.

Nobody has ever set foot in Chaos Dungeon, as it is situated deep within the Fragmented lands. The first adventuring party that does, however, will most definitely encounter horrific, twisted creatures that the mind can barely comprehend.

worldInfo.keys: novgorod,the orc lands, orc lands,orc homeland
worldInfo.entry: The Orcs homelands are cold and snowy, inhabited by bands of ruthless, roving orcs. They are north off Erleggon, and many crusades are sent up here by Mercia, all destined to fail.

Perma Dungeon is located in Novgorod and is inhabited by ice elementals that can freeze Adventurers and turn their icy carcasses against their party. If one wants to venture into here, torches will be the only thing ensuring their survival.

Cradletide is the Shadow Elves homeland. It is located even further north than Novgorod, on a delta called Shrieking Bay. Very few Shadow Elves live there anymore, and very few adventurere go upto Cradletide. The Shadow Elves of Cradletide are, however, more hospitable and friendly than their southern bretheren in Erleggon.

The Adventurers Guild was formed shortly after the spreading of the Fragment across Erleggon by Fidel Aventúr. It is the go to guild for adventurers to party up with others, accept quests, and delve into dungeons. Its members are all eager adventurers, and the more experienced ones are willing to provide all the help they can give.

Adventurer's skill in Erleggon is determined by "Levels". The more monsters an adventurer kills and the more quests they do, the more they level up. When you level up, you gain access to new skills, spells, and equipment.

actions.text:
...and see a rather amiable-looking woman looking down at you with a gentle smile.

"The stowaway is finally awake, I see. Do you care to tell me what you're doing in my tavern, or how you even got in here without the key?" she questions you, surprisingly pleasant about the whole situation.

You explain to her that your name is Ricky and you aren't from here and why you need to get home now!.. and she simply gives a glum laugh.

"I see... another poor soul brought into our world from the Fragment. You're lucky you ran into me first, or you might have been burned at the stake for being a monster!" she tells you in an eerily cheerful voice.

"In any case, welcome to Erleggon. Our world is slowly being devoured by the Fragment, which brings monsters into our world to harass our people. You ended up the town of New Hope, a neutral faction between the 6 kingdoms which also is rarely attacked by the monsters from the Fragment."

That's when it hits you... this is the world that you were creating! The Fragment must be the bits you never got around to finishing... but why would it produce devil spawn?

"You look quite concerned." the woman notices, interjecting your thoughts. "If you want to join the fight to beat back the Fragment, then you can join the Adventurer's guild! It was founded by Fidel Adventúr shortly after the Fragment was discovered to actively fight back against it. Bloodshed, fame and glory don't exactly suit me... but it might be your cup of tea!"

Right. You hadn't drafted the dungeons or quests yet, so technically this world had no concept of 'adventuring' until now. 

"I need to get back to work, stranger, but you're welcome to rest." the woman says before leaving you to your thoughts

You don't know what compelled you to do this, but you find yourself at the front desk of the local Adventurer's Guild. 

"Ah, another level one looking to seek their fortune in battle! Very well then, there's just a short process to get you into the guild.

Are you willing to go forth and battle great foes?"
"Yes"
"Good! Then there's nothing more for it, say 'bout right then!
> You say "What are Levels?"
"What are Levels?
Oh don't you know? They're very important things! If you're low on a level, sometimes our member may still have spare weapons or potions for you. It's up to the officer's discretion though."
> You say "Where can i find quests to do?"
"By the statue of Louis the Great, there's a board with some of our members requesting for assistance on certain tasks. You should probably just stick to the ones that interest you though.
> You approach the quest board.
The quest board is very large, made of wood (with a map on it). It says "Help requested." at the top, with several other requests below that. under that there are several times where "help"
requests were requested, with the results below that.
"Help requested." It says, as you read the request below it.
A giant is threatening the villagers of Nivellia. He's taken their hero, and locked him in his tower.

We need a hero to rescue him.
"Hmm, I don't think you should do that one." The Man says, looking over your shoulder. "Not sure if it's going to end well."
> You say "Do i have to kill the gigant or just save the hero?"

"Either one will do. Gigant can't be freed by anyone else without extreme measures.
"Then we need to kill the gigant."
"You sure about that?" he asks, "

the hero's pretty popular around there. Gigant and his mom live in the tower you see, it would be very hard to get him out without killing both of them."
"I'll do it."

"You sure?" he asks again.
"Yeah.
> You see all the specificatoins of the quest.
"Hmm, alrighty then." The man says, picking up the quest and handing it to you. your name is underlined. "Good luck, I'm sure you'll do fine."

he says, winking.
"Thanks." you say, walking off.
Once home, you decide to read the quest first before taking it.
The quest itself is pretty straight forward. Go to the Nivellian village of Truce Mill, and rescue their hero, who has been kidnapped by the evil wizard Gigant.
> You ask yourself what kind of magic you are able to use.

You are able to use Fire. Ice is also able to be used, but only by those that have been trained in it.
You also are able to use a weapon proficient in whatever element you use.
> You see what kind of equipment you have on you.
You have on you, a small backpack, a wooden sword, a silver dagger, and a gold iphone.
> You say "I need to do some shopping to get armor"

"Very well."
You decide that you need to do some shopping, but first you need to know where the best place to get armor would be.
You remember seeing a store earlier, with a lot of armor. You also remember thinking that there was a difference in price between the mail and chain armor and the plate armor.

You remember that the armor store seemed to be a little further away from your house.
You walk to the armor store, and upon seeing it, you start to feel anxious.
"Um, hi?"

you say, as the door is pushed open, and a small child runs out. You quickly go to apologize, but the man behind the door smiles.
"Don't worry son, I did that once too."
> You say "I need a leather armor"

"Aye, we have some of the best leather here. Wait here, I need to get some plates made."
The man grabs a few armors and goes to work.

After about a few minutes, he puts a few armors on a horse and leads it outside.
"Hop on," he says, "it's too heavy to carry."
You get on the horse, and you ride through the village.
> You go to the quest's village.

Almost immediately, you see the small Nivellian village.
You can see tiny figures moving about; some working in the fields, others fishing, still others simply walking around.

Soon, you see a single, brown dot moving about on the road. It's the kidnapped child.
You squint your eyes, in attempt to see who he is.
As he gets closer, you see that he's a little boy, no older than ten. He looks lost in thought, as he holds a bag of bread on his shoulder.
> You seek the Gigant's lair.

As you approach the village, you can see that it's almost empty.
Most of the citizens seem to be rushing to leave the village. They must think you're another undead threat.
The kidnapper must be hiding somewhere in the village. You can imagine the thrill he'll get from killing you and hiding your corpse; this will be a perfect opportunity.
You see the leader of the Nivellians. He's a tall, knight-like figure. White hair strains his neck as he swears.
> You wave at him.

You wave at the leader, smiling. He smiles back, but keeps to himself.
You spot a scarecrow in a nearby field. As you approach, it waves its arms, and bowing its legs.
> You say "So you know about a gigant, that kidnapped a hero?"

The scarecrow nods.
"Yes, yes! He is in the castle, in the throne room."

"Thank you."
You hop on the horse, and ride towards the castle.
In the distance, you can see the Gigant's Castle, a large, black castle made of stone.
> You say "Well i shouldn't just get in by the front door, that would be stupid"

You look at your small map, and see a secret passage on the left side of the map.
"I'll probably need to use that," you think aloud.

It's a secret passage to the dungeon.
"Bravo, the player thinks," the scarecrow says in a monotone voice, "he'll use a secret passage into the dungeon.

That's how these things are always done."
You feel a sense of pride. "It's not like I've ever traveled this part of the world before.

I'm not actually a bad strategist."
The scarecrow nods, as if in agreement.
"Now," the scarecrow says, "
> You search for the hidden passage to the Gigant's Castle.

You feel around in the passage, finding a small, wooden door. You open it slowly, to find yourself in a stone hallway.
You turn left, and walk down the dark hallway.

After a few minutes, you come to a door on the left. You open it, to reveal stairs going down.
You nod, and begin walking down.
As you walk down, you hear laughter.

You turn, to see a large group of daqualaars standing at the bottom of the stairs. They laugh as you back away in fear.
You turn again, and continue walking.
> You observe the daqualaars.
The daqualaars are a large group of ladies that consist of nothing but skin and claws. Their eyes are just... empty.
> You see your surroundings.
You're in a dark hallway. There's a single torch that burns feebly on the wall. You can just see the door at the end of the hallway.
> You throw a fireball to the daqualaara.

You concentrate, and fire a fireball at a large group of daqualaars. You hit six or seven daqualaars.
"Bravo! The player did not get scared and used his magic!"

the scarecrow claps with glee.
"Should I use Ice magic?" you ask.
"Yes, yes, do!" the scarecrow eagerly replies.
> You say "Nah, i will just charge the rest of them with my dagger, there is no poimt in wasting my mana"
You charge the daqualaars. They're scared, and they're running towards you.

"Charge!" the scarecrow says.
You run towards them, and throw your dagger. The first daqualaar catches it, and holds it to her chest in adoration.
"My hero!"
> You say "Wha-"
She snatches your dagger out of the daqualaar's hands, and bites into your hand. You yell in pain, and grab the daqualaar's mouth, pulling her head away from you.
> You create an ice dagger and rip the creature's belly with it.
You create a small dagger of ice in your other hand. You stab it into the daqualaar's belly. She yells, and you pull your hand away from her.

"You must kill them all!" the scarecrow yells. "Or they will kill you! I told you this!"
You nod.
> You finish the rest of them with your dagger.

You finish the remaining daqualaars with your daggers.
"There! I told you I could do it!" the scarecrow says with pride.
You rest on the ground, catching your breath.
> You keep exploring the Gigant's castle.
You continue exploring the castle, looking for any sort of weakness that you can find. You find a large library at the end of a long hallway. The Gigant's library is bigger than your native one.
As you continue to explore, you find a room with a large book lying on a table in the middle of the room. It's titled "The Soul Reaver".
> You flip the book's pages, looking dor something that catches your attention.
You flip through the pages, looking at the various drawings and diagrams of blades and guns. There is nothing that catches your eye until you get to the very last page, at the very end of the book.

You pull out your golden marker, and circle the page number.
By now, you've explored pretty much every inch of the castle. Gigalum must have hundreds of blades hidden in here.
> You take the page with you.

You take the page with you.
Gromwell is a large castle. You've been walking for what seems like hours, and Gigalum doesn't seem to be any closer. You need to rest.
> You search for the castle's servant's dorms.

The scarecrow leads you through a maze of hallways, until you reach a large set of stairs. There is a door on the left side of the landing.
"That's where I sleep," he says.
> You say "The Gigant doesn't come to this part of the castle?"
"No, he stays away from the servant's dorms. He finds them to be weak and unworthy of wielding his blade."

You head down the stairs, and into the pitch darkness of the staircase. You feel your way along the walls, until you reach a T.
"This is it."
> You search for a room you like.

"Which room do you want?" the scarecrow asks.
You look around you, at the bleak stone walls. There is a small window high on the wall, letting in a little bit of light.
There is a door to the left, a little bigger than the others. There is a large iron gate in front of it, with a sign on it that says "Gromwell".
> You say "This one seems ok"
"This one seems fine. Although perhaps some of the furniture could be replaced, as it is a bit dusty."
You enter the room, and take a seat on one of the chairs. The chair is much bigger and softer than the other chairs in this castle, which seems very odd to you.
> You get in the bed.
The big bed in front of you fills you with a sense of awe, as you've never slept in a bed so luxurious. You get in it and close your eyes, drifting off to sleep.
You wake up and scratch your neck, looking around the room. There is a feather in the corner of your eye, and you look to see where it came from.

You grab it, and see a small purple porcupine laying in the same corner of the room.
You back away slowly, watching it instinctively hide itself.
> You get out of the room and go to the hall to continue exploring the Gigant's castle.
You leave the room and move on through the castle, as you explore more of it. You head further in, into the humongous dining hall. Giant chandeliers hang from the ceiling, with hundreds of candles.
The long table is set for a twelve-course meal, with lots of meats, cheeses, breads, and desserts. You wonder where you could possibly have the appetite to consume something so filling.
Moving on, you enter the throne room. Gigant sits on his throne, giant head looming over the citizens of the kingdom.

Gigant looks at you and lets out a roar.
"Ah! You're awake, excellent!" Gigant says. "I was going to see you soon anyway. How did the journey to my castle go?"
> You say "Oh, it went very well. I had to fight some monsters tho, they were a little anoying, not as much as that scarecrow that follows me around. So: how you have been?"

Giant chuckles, which causes his head to shake and his eyes to widen.
"Oh, yes, how have I been? Well, let's see..." Gigant says, laying on his throne.
gian tugs at his beard, deep in thought.
"I'm bored. I'm bored, and the kingdom isn't selling any alcohol anymore. That's my main problem right now. I'm trying to think up ways to amuse myself," Gigant says.
> You say "Oh, you are looking for ways to amuse yourself? That's why you kidnapped the hero?"

"Yeah, I needed to find something to do. The hero is here, so I can't just go off attacking the kingdom for fun, but..."
Giant looks down.
"I feel like I'm not really doing anything worthwhile recently... Could be all this royalty business is getting to me. I should just go back to being a hermit again," Gigant says.
> You say "So... could you pelease relase the hero so i can get my reward?"
"Pfft, if I gave you the hero, all it would do is get him taken away by the guards again. No, you have to earn your reward. I'll give you a quest."
Giant leaps off his throne and strides towards a door in the back of the room. He opens it, revealing a large staircase.

Gigant begins walking up the stairs, and you follow.
You begin walking up the stairs after Gigant. As you continue to walk up the massive staircase, your footstep echo throughout the castle.
As you continue to walk, the staircase continues to get narrower and narrower, and the echo of your footsteps grows louder and louder. It's kind of like an old-school audio horror game.
At the top of the stairs, you find yourself on a platform, overlooking the castle walls and the forests. Gigant stands there, staring out at the forest.

"Do you know where the hero is?" you ask.
"No," Gigant admits. "I was really hoping that he'd bump into one of my men and we could capture him again."
> You say "WHAT, did he escaped?"
"Yeah, about a week ago. The fool has been walking around the kingdom, trying to find his family."
> You say "Oh my god, he is going to get himself killed. I need to find that idiot now."
"I could help you look for him. He wouldn't be hard to find in this area, given his fame."

"Yeah, I need to find him fast, because if you release him..."
Giant raises a large, thick eyebrow.
"If I release him, then what?" Gigant asks.

"Well, I'm going to... I'm going to have to kill you."
Giant lets out a booming, hysterical laugh.
"Oh my dear lord, you're only a child!" Giant laughs.

"Oh, please, you need to lighten up! There's no way you could hurt me!"
"I don'. I'm serious."
"Well then, prove it."
The Gigant drops down to all fours, and leans up against the wall. His massive forearms are parallel to the ground, making a "v" shape with his arms.
His elbows are bent at 90 degree angles, and his hands are up in a fighting position. He looks like a monster, all four legs and stony face with a gaping maw, ready to strike.
> You say "Huh, i don't think violence is the answer"

"Fine then," the Gigant groans.
The Gigant begins walking towards the stairs, with you following after him. He begins walking to the right, around a corner.
> You say "So, do you know where the hero could have go?"

"Not a clue." Giant grumbles. "The last thing I heard was him going into the forest, but he might have gone further in."
Giant stops, and turns to you.

"However, I do know where the guards sleep. If you find him, please wake them up. I'll head to bed."
You nod, and begin walking northward.
> You head to the forest, looking for a trace of the hero.

As you make your way through the forest, an owl flying by lets out a shriek.
"Listen," you say out loud. "Do you hear that?"
"Hear what?"

"That. Sound."
You pause, and listen again.
"I can't hear anything."
You slowly turn your head to look at Olive, who's walking beside you.

You see her frown, pulling out a dagger. She begins twirling it in her hands, waiting for you to continue leading the way.
"There's nothing out here," you call back to her.

"So you say."
You take a few steps forward, stopping as the trees begin to thin. In front of you is a large forest clearing. In the middle of it is a Tavern.
The Tavern has a large open space, with long wooden tables. Perhaps twenty chairs are set around the tables. Perhaps two dozen people are sitting at the tables, eating, drinking, or talking.

undoneWindow.text:
"Fine then, prove that you're my friend."
"What?"
"Prove that you're my friend. Help me open this box."

"Yes. I'm bored," Gigant says.
Giant rubs his giant chin.
"I have a request. A quest. If you would take it."
"What is it?"

Giant nods, smiling.
"Yeah, I needed to get that hero guy again. I'm going to need him to come back to the castle."
"Hero guy?"

you ask.
"Yeah, you haven't heard of him? He's really popular in general! He helps me out a lot in fighting off boredom. He's fantastic," Gigant says.

You walk along the hallways, searching for a safe place to hide while the little purple quills prick your fingers.
You find a door that is slightly open, and walk inside.

You open the door and see a man standing there. "I'm looking for Gromwell," you say.
He looks at you disapprovingly, as if he thinks you're some kind of thief.

You go to pick it up, and you find a note.
Congratulations on escaping from Gromwell!
I am glad to see that you made it out of there alive.
The sun beams in through the window as you open your eyes. This isn't your room. Your name isn't on the door.
As you do so, you feel as if you are shrinking into the chair. You don't like it here. You try to stand up, but nothing happens.
"I'm the castle's servant. Please, don't tell my master."

You walk down the dark hallway, and once again, there's a scarecrow sitting in the middle of the hallway.
"Ah, you've returned. I assume you met my sister, the princess?"

"And now, you shall be carried to the nearest town!" the scarecrow says. "The hero of Truce Mill! cherish this moment, for it will never happen again!"
You walk forward.

The scarecrow looks at you, with a more serious look.
"My name is Edgar. I'm the king of the daqualaars."
"I'm Harribor," you reply.

"How?" you ask.
"The birds told me! They see everything! They told me where the daqualaars went, and after a few tries, they told me where the cactii went!"

"Ah, there are a few more tests to go through!" the scarecrow says. "Quick, run through the rings and stab your opponent!"
You look at the five coloured rings on the floor.

You look up, to see a large white figure looming over you.
Your throat is crushed by the creature's giant hand, as you watch helplessly.
You don't die right away.

No doubt they want to turn you into snack.
Unfortunately, the scarecrow gets in the way. He's much too big, and when he moves forward, you end up charging right into him.
the scarecrow claps, "Now, the scarecrow will throw the player a bone. The scarecrow might have a hint..."
The scarecrow stares intently at you, as if reading your mind.

You are in a forest, surrounded by trees. The sky is dark, the only light coming from the moon and the stars.
There is a path on the ground, leading away from the edge of the forest.

You move forward, readying your sword. The creatures seem to be moving faster, and are now surrounding you.
The creatures lunge at you, as you swing your sword.

You stop, and listen. It's coming from down the stairs.
You walk down the stairs, stopping at each landing to wait for the laughter to stop. Each floor has a different pitch of laugh.

The leader turns, and you wave. He gives a small smile, which you return.
"What brings you here?" he asks. You explain that you were sent to escort him back to his village.

You approach the child, and call out, "Where is the nearest path leading off the road?"
He looks at you. His eyes widen when he recognizes you from earlier.

"Where are you going?" you ask.
"To the border."
"What's on the other side?"
"A quarry."

As you read the description, you realize that knights in shining armor aren't exactly a thing in this world. In fact, the only knights you've ever seen in your entire life have worn red leather with silver trim.
(This is a fantasy adventure. The quest: Kill Crimson Gigant and his Mom. You have to kill both of them. If you try saving the only hero in the world, you will fail).
You read the quest over.

The Boss nods his head.
"Alright! Then let's go to the armory and get you some armor! We have a large supply so you shouldn't have too many problems finding something to fit!"

The woman frowns.
"Why would a level-one want to know such things? We're all equal in the Guild, so long as we make a reasonable attempt at saving our own asses in battles.

title: You are a girl that has been captured by the barbarians
memory:
You are a young peasant girl called Vivanne.

You wield a two handed axe.
You have 2 knives.
You wear a thick padded tunic a metal helmet and a face mask.

You are currently being chased by the barbarians because you escaped from their camp.

actions.text:
You are a young peasant girl called Vivienne. You have been captured during a raid against your village.

Your captors are barbarians, and they have taken you to their Barbarian Hall. The barbarians, all of them burly and muscular guys, are now partying in the hall, eating, drinking, distributing the loot and telling high tales of their successful raid. There is a general festive mood among them.

You are now inside a large communal cage with other girls that were also captured. Many of them are crying or have just resigned to their fate and look glum and defeated. These barbarians are well known for making slaves out of the girls they capture, and the most beautiful are assigned to serve in their hall. The less fortunate are sent to work in the fields like beasts of burden.

But you are a resourceful and energetic girl, the kind of female protagonist that could star in a Disney movie, and becoming a slave of these brutes is not in your plans. You have to escape!

One of the barbarians seems to have noticed you already.
He is a huge brute of a man with long curly black hair and wielding a long axe. He stomps over to the cage and leans against it with one elbow, staring at you with dark eyes.
> You say "Look that way"
You point over one shoulder and say in a low voice "They're watching us." The barbarian grunts in acknowledgement and looks away.
> You put your hands in his chin and at the top of his head, and with you swift move break his neck.
You pull the hands up and from the chin to break the man's neck. You feel the bone snapping as his head flies back, hitting the wall.
> You grab the keys he has in his belt.
The keys hang from the chain around the barbarian's huge belly. You reach up and with one hand you try to grab the keys, but it is no use. They are just out of your reach.
> You pull the barbarian corpse a little closer.
Sticking one leg through the gap in the bottom of the cage, you move the corpse so that your foot is on the outside and you can reach the keys.
> You open the door of your cell.
The door to your cage is heavy and made of thick metal, it is a struggle to move it. As you lean against the door with one shoulder you manage to move the door just enough to squeeze out.
You stand up and look around. There is a long room filled with cages, some occupied by prisoners, others empty. Down one side of the room is a line of doors that presumably lead to sleeping quarters.
> You grab the dead barbarian's axe.

Grinning, you grab the axe from the floor and pull it along the ground until it points at the hanged man.
Looking up, you see the prisoners in the cage are watching you.
> You break the other cages locks.
With the axe you smash the locks off the other cages. Within seconds the prisoners are free and jumping out of their cages.
> You try to search the armory to arm the prisioners without being noticed.
You run down the center of the hall, passing other doors until you reach a soldiers armory. There are two big doors of thick metal.
You grab two sharp throwing knives from a table and shove them into your belt. You grab a thick padded tunic from a rack, pulling it on. You grab a metal helmet with a face mask, putting it on.
> You try to push the armory's doors open.
The doors are chained and locked. You grab a large metal bar and start to smash the door with all your strength. The door doesn't move.
Frustrated, you throw down the bar and leave the armory. You head back towards the prisoners but you pass the hanging cage on the way.

It catches your eye and you wonder who the man in the cage is.
You slow down and stare at it, trying to make out the figure through the thick metal, but it is too dark.
As you get close, you realize that it is a civilian. He is clutching a torn picture in his hands and his eyes are wide with fear.
You pass him by and continue heading towards the prisoners.
The hall leads into a large cafeteria-like room where a large group of prisoners are gathered. They watch two guards as they stand by a table covered with bones and the skins of dead animals.
> You press your body to a wall to not get noticed.
With great effort, you manage to get into a small alcove and pull your hat low over your eyes. You do not want to be recognized by the guards as one of the men who escaped.
> You watch around you.

Two guards stand by the prisoners, grinning and chatting with them. The guards are perhaps teenagers, new recruits sent to the fort by mistake. They are boys, unskilled and poorly trained, eager for a challenge.
> You try to sneak near then to make a surprise attack.
You walk forward slowly, keeping your head down and your hands in your coat pockets. The guards are having a conversation with one of the prisoners, a young man with a strong, fit build.

They are debating the merits of some rock band, seemingly unaware that you are nearby.
Just as you are about to reach them, you hear a shout.

The guards have seen you!
You raise your head just in time to see the younger guard point at you and then the older one draw his gun from his side.
> You swiftly crush the nearest guard skull with your axe and throw one of your knives to the other.
You swing your axe and strike the guard in the side of his head, killing him instantly. You pull out your knife and stab the guard, jumping back as he collapses.

You watch as the gun flies from his hand before turning to the boy.
The boy stares at you with a shocked expression on his face before sprinting away, passing behind the farthest guard.
You run after them, but the guards shout at you and point their guns at you. You stop and watch as they usher the prisoners into a defensive position, appearing to strategize.
> You get cover.
You dive behind a horse carcass, pulling your knife from the guard's chest as you do so. The boy grabs the gun and prepares to fire, but before he can, you strike.

You lunge forward, driving the knife into his throat. You push the body off you as the other guards run over.
"What the fuck did you do that for?" One of them says.

"That kid was a good shot!"
"He killed our friend!" Another one says, "And that guy over there..."
You stab him through the throat, blood spurting out.
The guards open fire, bullets thudding into the carcass. You wipe blood off your face as you hear more men approaching.
