"Magic. Specifically, enchantment."
"What's so hard about that?"
The woman laughs.
"You don't think someone like me couldn't enchant myself or a rock to drop below the ground?"
She asks. "I need an expert, and that someone happens to be a little six-year-old girl."
> You say "Any dangers I should be aware of"

"Not unless you count the brain capacity of a lizard. But I'm sure you knew that."
"Yeah, I did."
"Good."
You nod your head, looking at her.
> You search dor the girl.

You search the house for the girl, but don't find her.
"Ah, looks like I'm a little too late this time." The woman says.

"Where did you last see her?" You ask.
"I saw her run into that house over there." The woman says, pointing to a house a little ways down the road.
"Thanks."
> You use a track spell.

You run towards the house, jumping up and narrowly clearing the front door. You quickly ascend the stairs to the second floor, where you see a little girl standing in front of a wall covered with pictures.
"Hello."
> You kill her.
You quickly walk up to the little girl, lifting your rifle up as you aim at her head.

"Drop the gun."
You hear a voice shout, looking down to see the girl standing there holding a small gun of her own, staring at you.
> You blast her swiftly.

You pull the trigger, firing a bullet directly through the girl's chest. She falls backwards, blood bursting out of her mouth as she breathes heavily.
"You can... can put the gun down."
> You put the girl in a bag.
You quickly walk over to the girl, grabbing her and putting her in a large backpack. You sling it over your shoulder and run out of the house, finding yourself on a road again.
> You give it to the woman.

You walk up to the woman, who is looking around cautiously.
"Thanks." She says, taking the bag. "I have to go now, my associate will be here soon."
"Wait!"

You shout. "You said you needed an expert on enchantment, how would killing a child help you do that?"
"It's complicated." She says, turning around and walking off.
> You say "I dont care as long as i get paid"

"Good, got it in one."
She takes out her phone and makes a quick call, ending the conversation by nodding at you.

"Alright, the job is done, now if you don't mind I have to go, he'll be here soon."
You nod your head, and she takes off running.

You run after her for a bit, before she slows down and eventually stops.
"Alright, let's do the deed." She says, turning to you.

"You can carry me in your arms, I'm pretty light."
"Hold on, I can't be picking you up, people will see us."
"Ah, yes you are right. Let me down."

She gets down, and you walk with her to the end of the street.
"Listen, I'm not picking you up again."
"Ah, yes you are right. Come on, pick me up."

"No."
"Ah, yes you are right."
"Alright, alright, I'll pick you up."
"Thank you, sir."
You lift her up and start running.

"Alright, here we are." She says.
You walk into a large house, the door opening as you enter. The man who spoke to you earlier stands there, holding a shotgun.

"I'm in."
"Alright, come in, come in."
You walk inside, following her as she leads you into a large room.

A man lies on the ground, chained to the floor. Two other men stand on either side of him, grinning as they look at him.
"Well, this is it." The woman says.

"The last survivor."
You look at the man, a pretty boy with an angular face and long, messy hair.

His eyes are shut, he must be asleep.
"You know the rules. No talking." One of the men says, as you nod.
You walk forward, crouching by the man.
You quickly search his pockets, finding a set of keys, a lighter, a pack of cigarettes and a lighter, some copper wire, a screwdriver and a small knife, and a set of keys.

"What are you doing?" The woman asks.
"He's got the keys, lighter, some equipment and a knife." You say.
"Good, good, let's get going."

The man says.
You stand, walking to the man's right side. You open the door and begin fiddling with the locks, opening the door and grabbing the backpack.

You pull it inside and shut the door, locking it.
"Alright boys, let's get to work."
You walk over to the chained man, and kneel down.
You shine the flashlight onto his face, seeing tears and mucus clogging his nose and throat. He coughs and hacks as more liquid comes out, a clear substance that smells foul but isn't blood.

"Please, stop." He manages to choke out.
"You can speak?" You ask, surprised.
"Yeah...yeah, I can speak." He says.
"I just...I don't want to die. I don't want to fall asleep. Please, I've got...pills..."

You see a small pack of pills on the floor, and pick them up.
"Pills?"
"Yeah...please...I'll give you all the pills you want...if you don't kill me."
> You turn to the woman.

"What's his name?" You ask.
"His name?" She says, seemingly distracted by her phone. "I don't know, he never told me."
"Why is he chained up?

Does he have a dangerous look about him or something?"
"Eh, he's not chained up. He just can't move, that's all."

You begin to feel uneasy about this. The man coughs and hacks as more liquid comes out, but stops when he's empty.
"Come on." The woman says, ending the call.

"I need to get to work. Have fun playing with the little guy."
She walks out, leaving you alone with the chained man. You look at him, then at the backpack on the floor.
> You say "You didn jore me as a babysitter"

"You didn't ask me to babysit." You say. "I'm not some crazy person who just listens to what you say and does it."
"That's exactly what you are." The man says.
> You say "Im not staying here just waiting for orders, there are best people for that"

"You'll stay and listen, or I'll hurt you."
"You don't want to do that." You say.
"Fine." He says.
You look at the backpack on the floor, then back to the man. You see the tiniest sliver of metal near his mouth. It looks like a key to a padlock.
> You walk around.

You walk slowly, shining the flashlight around the room. You see two doors in the distance.
"So why am I chained up here?" The man asks.
> You say "Shut it"

"What?"
"I said shut it."
"No, tell me why you chained me up here.
> You ignore him.
You ignore him, and shine the flashlight on the room. It's a relatively small room.

There's a dirty mattress on the floor, a dirty pile of blankets, and two dressers. One is filled with dirty clothes, and the other is filled with nothing but a few disgusting jars of bodily excretions.
> You say "You watch him im going out"

"You think you can just leave?"
"Yes, I think it's pretty apparent that I can."
"Then you don't think at all. You stay."
> You say "I dont tale orders from you"

"I didn't say you were supposed to leave, I said you watch him."
"Whatever, just let me out of this cage so I can get back to work."
> You leave.
You quickly hurry up to the door, opening it and walking out into the main room of the house. You close the door behind you.
> You Look for the woman
You walk through the house, shining your flashlight in dark corners and behind closed doors. You look in the foyer, the kitchen, the bathroom, the living room, all the rooms you can think of.
All the while, you wait for the man to start talking, but he remains silent. You look in his direction, but his head is hanging down and his mouth is shut tight.

You don't know if he's fallen asleep, or if he's just ignoring you.
You decide to test him. You walk over to his side of the cage, and stand there.
> You practice summoning familiars to kill time.

You spend about twenty minutes summoning creatures to try to get them to do something interesting. Finally, you give up and decide to sit in the dark and listen to the man's ragged breathing and see how long you last.

Hours pass as you wait. Minutes turn into days as days turn into weeks. Weeks turn into months as months turn into years.
Finally, you hear a noise from the man's direction.

You walk over to the side of the cage and peek at him.
You see the man, still chained up, but with no longer any trace of the chain shackles once were on his wrists and ankles.

He stands, pulling the dirty blanket off the mattress, and walks over to a corner of the room. He begins to cry.
As he cries, you leave the cage and walk back to the mattress.
> You say "What did you do"
"I DIDN'T DO ANYTHING.
> You use a restrainig spell.

You try to force the man to stop moving, but it doesn't work. He continues to move, dragging the mattress behind him as he waddles into the corner.
"Why are you doing this?"
> You try to restrain him again this time using 10% of your power.
You force your will onto the man, but find that he is resistant. Your efforts begin to tire you out as his crying and wailing moves you to tears.

"I'm not the monster!" He cries.
Suddenly, he breaks away from your mental restraints and sprints towards the door. You quickly try to restrain him again, but he is too fast.
You hear a loud noise as the chain breaks. You search for it, but you can't find it anywhere.
> You call her and tell her that it is free.

You walk over to the door and call for the woman, but there is no answer. You call several more times, but there is no answer.
You sit down and cry as the man continues crying in the corner.
You sit there until you can't see, then stand and pace back and forth. You pace there until your feet hurt, then walk in circles until your toenails bleed.
> You put a barrier in the room.
You quickly begin creating a barrier around the room. You can't concentrate on anything else but your task, and as you complete it, you feel better. The barrier is strong, but not impenetrable.
> You look for the woman.

You walk around the barrier, shining your flashlight ahead of you. You look around for the woman, but do not find her.
You hear the man cry again.
> You say "Im out"

"Thank you for not killing me."
"What?
"After you kill me, you will have to go back to the void, won't you?"
"

I'm not killing you."
"Yes, you are. I can tell by the chain on your neck.

You're a harbinger."
You pause, and shine your light on the man's neck. You notice a small silver chain attached to it.
"What does a harbinger do?"
"

Harbingers are given powers of judgment and control over death. We rule the living, and determine who lives and who dies."
"Why would you give someone powers of judgment and control over death?"
"

It's our job. Is it your job to determine who lives and who dies?"
"No."
"My name is Lawrence. What's yours?

"I'm a harber... har... uh..."
You can't think of anything to say, but he doesn't seem to care.

"We don't have time. You must choose whether to kill me or release me."
"I can't kill you.
> You say "It shall be"

You say "It shall be" as the words slip from your mouth.
"I have a mind of my own. You can't make me do anything."
"Yes I can."
> You do it.

You walk up to the man and look into his eyes. You see fear in them, but you also see resolve.
"It's OK. You don't have to do this."
"Yes, I do."
> You say "Ho, instead of running away you come straight at me"

"You don't know me, and you don't know why I'm here."
"I don't care. You're running away, which I'm not going to have a problem with.

Please turn around and bend over."
"What? How did you know I was going to run away?"
"I didn't. I was just hoping."
"Well, it doesn't matter.
> You say "Run or fight anyway youbare going to die"

"Fine."
He throws down his gun and raises his hands. You lead him to the back of the room and restrain him, taking his weapons.
"So, are you going to kill me?
> You say "Yes"

"Yes."
You put the shotgun to his temple and pull the trigger. The blast knocks you back and you hit the wall. The man slumps over as blood begins pooling on the floor.

"I think you just killed him."
"It's OK. He's just been released from his life."
You stand and search the body, finding a keycard.

You put it in the door, and it opens.
"After you."
You enter the hallway and follow the light. The hallway leads to a set of stairs.
You go up the stairs and find yourself in a basement.

"This is the last stand waiting basement."
You walk around the room, noticing a few infected in containers. There is also a large machine with a bunch of IV's connected to it.

A chair with a man in it. You recognize him as the psychopath that came for you.
"You must be Sam. I'm Jesse."
The man stares at you blankly.

"So what's with the tubes?"
"I'm being kept alive so the Alpha can be captured."
"How long do I have to keep you alive for?"
"As long as it takes."

"OK, well how about we get rid of the Alpha so you can die peacefully?"
"That would be ideal."
"How long will that take?

"I don't know, but the longer I'm kept alive, the more likely the infection in me gets out of control."
"So I should just kill you now so you don't get out of hand?"

"That would be ideal."
You look at the machine.
It's the life support for the Alpha. If you destroy it, then the psychopath dies. The problem is, there are also explosive bolts keeping it in place.

You could just bypass the explosive bolts, but the machine is heavy, and you don't want to tip over the container while you're moving the machine.
"Can I ask you another question?"
"Sure."

"Why did you choose to betray your fellow man and run away?
"I asked myself that question a lot.

I came up with an answer that I thought was the right one. I still do."
"What's that?"
"That man is not worth your dignity. That man is not worth your life.

That man is not worth your freedom."
You think about his words. You have to kill him, but does he have any merit?
"

I understand your reasons. I guess I'm just wondering if you're any better than the others."
"I try to be better than them."
"How?"
"By being intelligent for one thing."
"

By doing what?"
"By doing things. Lately I've been trying to fix the Boring Anonymous door."
"How is that better than what they do?"
"They hurt people.

I'm just trying to help."
"So what have you learned about how the world really works?"
"That people are stupid and always will be.

It's why we have organizations like the Professor to guide us."
"So why stop there? Why not be a criminal?"
"Because then I'd have to kill.
> You say "Do it"

"What?"
"Kill him. End his life now. If you learn how to stop the infection, then I'll teach you what you need to know about being a rebel.
> You say "Do it"
You quickly raise your shotgun, firing at point-blank range. The silver blast crushes the man's skull, and you hold your breath as you wait for the body to die.

The Alpha lets out a moan, and you find yourself panicking. But it soon gets back to business.
"OK. We're going to have to do this quickly. Where is the bunker?

I know you must have seen it."
"Down, down the stairs and to the right."
"How deep is it?

How many men have you got down there?"
"Just me and some others. We're pretty safe."
"How long will that take to get out of the stadium?
> You say "Do it"
The Alpha nods, and the two of you head down the stairs. The way is cramped, and you have to go single file at times.
Random chimp event apears

in the stairwell.
"Look! A new random event!" You say, startling the man in front of you.
The man turns, and you see a youngish face, probably in his late twenties.

He seems tired and has a resigned look about him.
"Random events? They're always popping up when you don't want them to." The man replies.
You shrug, and continue on.
Soon, you find yourself in a long corridor with grey walls and a drab colour scheme. The man is behind you, and doesn't say anything. You've already learned all you need to know about him.

"You never told me your name." You say.
"Warrick. That's about it, I'm afraid." He replies.
You decide to try another question.

"Do you know how we're going to stop the infection?"
He pauses for a moment, the first signs of emotion you've seen from him.
"I... I don't know. But we're running out of options. The vaccine doesn't work, and the cure is toxic. We've tried both."
The plot thickens

"I was hoping the vaccine would work. At least I could have tried." He continues.
"It doesn't work for everyone, and it only protects for a short time. We need a new approach."
> You do it.

You nod to Warrick, and the two of you move quickly down the corridor. The wall here is covered with posters. All propaganda, of course.
"Choose life."
"Join the revolution.
> You aproach menacingly.

"The human spirit can overcome anything."
"Join the inevitable."
You slowly move closer, as Warrick does likewise. The two of you are now less than ten feet from the man.
> You do it.
You step forward, pointing your shotgun directly at the infected man's head. You pull the trigger, and feel the recoil in your arm. The blast seems to take a little off the top of his head as well.
He falls back, letting out a moan that's half roar, and staggers towards you. You empty your gun into him, at one point even hitting him in the chest as he desperately tries to reach you.
> You become god and kill everyone.

You step back, shaking your head as you decide what to do.
"What now?" Warrick asks.
"Kill everyone.
"Everyone?"
"Everyone. The human spirit can overcome anything.
> You wake up in your classroom
You sit up quickly in bed, panting as you try to get your bearings. You look around, and notice that you're back in the school.

That's when you notice the sunlight streaming through the window, and remember what happened. You look around, and notice that you're covered in blood. You pause, suddenly concerned.
"Someone get into my room!"

You hear Mr. Gaange shout from across the room.
You shake your head and get up, heading to the bathroom. Once there, you look in the mirror.
You're pretty sure you're alive, but you're not sure about your wound. It's on the left side of your chest, just below your clavacleip.
You're not even sure how you got it. Your wound doesn't look like any bullet wound you've ever seen in person or even on TV. There's no exit wound, and it's more of a...

Score, really.
You shake your head as you realize you need to tell someone about this. You open your mouth to do so, when you hear a knocking on your door.
"Hello?" Mr.

Gaange says. "Anybody in there?"
You pause, considering whether or not to tell him the truth.
"Yes.

me in here." You call back.
"Ok, open the door."
You open the door, and Mr. Gaange is there. He raises an eyebrow when he sees the blood on your clothes.
"
You know, you could at least take off your clothes before coming to my room." He points out. "It's pretty gross when students enter a teacher's bathroom naked.
I mean, I suppose it's better than walking in naked with their parents, but it still is quite distasteful.

You pause, suddenly realizing he now knows the truth.
"Ah, I see. Well, I suppose it's not a bad place to be shot. You must have caught a pretty clean shot.
Either that, or the bullet is just incredibly small. I don't know. Where were we?

Oh, right. class. You asked me what would happen if everyone in the world were killed. I'm sure you can guess."
You nod eagerly.
"Death. Life without end.
Kids, do you know what happens when there is no more life? When there is no one left to love, to laugh with, to share experiences and tears with? There is no more anything. That's what happens.
When everything is dead, then what? Nothing. That's what. So if everyone were to die, the world would end. And that's what will happen.

The world will end. But not for... Well, not for a very long time."
You pause, wondering how to ask this next question.
"Mr. Gaange?"
"Yes?"
"

What happens when the world ends?"
Mr. Gaange pauses, before smiling.
"That, my child, is what make life so wonderful. What happens next?
Only time will tell.

But I promise you this. Even when the world ends, life goes on. That's what make living so wonderful. Time to wake up, class is over."
You pause, before raising an eyebrow.
"

I'm still alive?"
"You're still alive. Now, get out of here."
You pause, before raising an eyebrow.
"

Why?"
"Because the world hasn't ended yet, and I haven't lost my job.

Now, go wake up your friends, and get out of here."
You pause, thinking.
"Are you going to be there?"
Mr. Gaange pauses, before smiling.
"Of course.

I'm sorry, but I can't miss the end of the world. Now, get out of here, I have a class to teach."
You nod, before heading off to wake up your friends.
"

So what happened?" Haylon asks as you all sit in the cafeteria.
"Death.

But Mr. Gaange said that it doesn't matter, because life goes on. And we will survive, and grow stronger." You say.
The group is silent for a moment.
"

Well, I guess that's one way to look at it. Guess I'll see you guys later." You say.
"See you later, Jesse.

Thanks for what you did." Elios says.
"Of course, sir.

See you later, Kyle." Jesse says.
"See you later, Jesse.

Be careful, OK?" Kyle says.
"You too, man.

Thanks again."
"Alright, I'm off. Later, gents.

Take care, Ophelia." Elios says.
"Bye, Elios.

Thanks for what you did." Ophelia says.
"My pleasure, dear. Always a pleasure doing business with a strong willed woman.

I'll have to introduce you to my son some day."
"I look forward to it, Elios. Bye, everyone.
> You wake up in the battlefield.
You awaken in a large room with several wounded Oalkwardners and a lot of blood. One of the Oalkwardners begins to head over to you.
> You materialize a gigant made of pure mana around you.
You quickly begin to channel your mental forces into the gigant. As you do, you find it starting to come together.
> You say "Behold my Susanoo!"

You put all your mental resources into the gigant, and immediately feel a surge of energy fill you. You smile as a grand meld of your mental forces are combined to create a being of immeasurable power.
You gaze over the wounded and bleeding Orcs. They seem to stare at you in awe, as if you are a great warrior of old that has returned to slay their foes.
> You slaughter everyone.
You crush their bones, rend their flesh from their bodies and tear them apart. You crush their bones, rend their flesh from their bodies and tear them apart.

It is only after your rampage of blood, gore and death that you realize something is wrong.
The door has not opened.

You wonder what this means, but you don't have time to ponder, as you notice the Oalkwardner approaching you once more.
It stands before you, staring at you.

The Gigalith appears to be more wounded than when you left it, and covered in blood.
"I see you have failed to open the door. That is unfortunate." The Oalkwardner says.

"I did everything you told me to do." You answer.
"Yes, you did." The Oalkwardner says. "Now, the world will end. How unfortunate.

I have a last request."
"What?"
"I am a healer. I could save the world, if you would let me heal it."
"You cannot be a healer.

You're an Oalkwardner."
"I'm a lot of things I suppose I am. But I'm asking you as a friend to let me save the world.
I don't know how to do it myself, I need a powerful being of good to help me. Would you do that for a friend?
Please?
> You rool eyes.

"Fine."
The Oalkwardner smiles and nods.
"Thank you." He says, and pulls out his dagger. He presses it to his throat.
> You wha...

The Oalkwardner smiles and begins laughing.
"What the hell are you doing?" You say, backing away from him.
"Goodbye, my friend."

He says, and presses the dagger to his throat.
Suddenly, a bright light shines from above, illuminating the room. You look up to see the power of the sun pouring over you.
The Gigalith's face burns, and he drops to the floor, rolling around in pain. You look to the Oalkwardner, who stares up at the light in awe.

"What the hell?" You say, shielding your eyes from the powerful light.
Suddenly, you feel a massive, burning pain hit your chest. You collapse to your knees, and then onto your face.

The Gigalith runs to you, helping you up.
"It's going to be alright." He says.
You groan in pain, as the Gigalith begins to transform back to his true self.

"FUCK! That burned!" He shouts, as his clothes begin to re-cover him.
The pain subsides, and you realize you were just burnt.

"Ah, you alright?" The Gigalith asks.
You stare at the burning Oalkwardner in awe. You then notice that the sun is beginning to set.

"The sun..." You say.
"It was the end of the world." The Gigalith finishes.

"And now it will rise again."
"Well, it was a fun while it lasted." You say.
"Indeed. Well then, shall we finish off this Oalkwardner before he gets himself killed?"

"Yeah."
You turn to the Oalkwardner, who is stumbling around, looking for his dagger.

"The end?" You ask.
"I'm afraid so. I tried to save it, but there wasn't enough time. Goodbye, my friend."

"Goodbye." You say, as the Gigalith grabs you, holding you up.
You step forward and sink the blade into the back of the Oalkwardner's neck, killing him.

The Oalkwardner falls forward, face first into the ground.
"Let's get out of here." The Gigalith says.
The sun has completely set by this point, and the Gigalith holds out a hand to you, helping you up. You stare at the ground, at the fallen Oalkwardner, and nod.

"Yeah." You say.
The two of you begin to leave the forest, back towards the camp.
"So, who's the svelk chick?" The Gigalith asks.
"What?"

You ask.
"I said, who's the svelk chick? You got something under your eye."
You look to your left and see a large splotch of dried blood.

"Oh, that's Bloodmaw." You say.
"Who?"
"One of the svelk mercs. Died earlier today."
"Oh, that Bloodmaw. Pity."
> You wake up.
You wake up in a cold sweat, and sit up. You take a look around, and see that you're in a small, dirty room, illuminated only by the bright red light of the rising sun.
You stand up, looking around. The room you're in seems to be the barracks of the forest beasts. There's a few wooden beds, a few tables, some cabinets, and little else.

undoneWindow.text:
You wake up in the morning, covered in dirt. You're sitting on the ground, back against a tree. The sun is out, and so is the Gigalith.
"You still alive?"
You concentrate and the air begins to resonate as a large ball of energy is formed around you. You feel very protected inside the sphere and can see the entire room.
> You use Susanoo.

You decide to draw out the sword first, as you do this, the armored shell surrounding your body increases in size. The armored shell is a mixture of bones, teeth and pieces of meat all welded together.
You grab the Oalkwardner, slashing his throat as he reaches for you with his other hand. You look around, seeing several dead bodies of your fellow Creation Club members, as well as the wounded.
You use your sword to easily bisect the head of the approaching Oalkwardner, who falls to the ground. You spot another approaching from the left.
> You say "Susanoo!"

"S... Susanoo?" The Oalkwardner asks.
"Yes, Susanoo! Don't you recognize him? He saved this village!"
"Nope, not me. Not anyone I recognize."
You sit up, your heart pounding. You look around, but don't seem to be missing anything. The men you were talking to are gone. You quickly check your pockets, and find nothing is stolen.
You open your eyes, staring into the darkness. You hear a slight groan, as one of the survivors in the room slowly wakes up.

"What... what happened?" You ask, waking up and finding yourself in the stadium.
"You killed all of them." The girl says.

"That would be ideal."
"So you can't tell me how long it's going to take to kill you?"
"I'm sorry, no."
You sigh and shake your head.

You walk up to the man and pat him on the shoulder. You don't know why you did it, but it seems to have worked.
"I understand. Thank you."

You begin to look for the woman. As you step out of the room, you hear the cries of a woman outside.
"Let her out!" You cry, and an old door opens up, revealing a staircase.

You call out for the ghost girl, and walk towards the rusted cage.
"It's free!" You say.
No reply comes, but you hear the noise of footsteps running in the distance.

You force the man to stop and stand there, panting as you watch him cry.
"Now tell me the truth," you say, "Did you do this?"
"No.

You use all your might to restrain him, and for a moment it looks like you've succeeded. The man is still, but you feel the strain on your body.
"You look tired." The man says.
> You again.

"I'M NOT DOING ANYTHING!
"Are you sure?"
"Yeah, I'm sure. Now leave me alone.
> You say "Did you unchain him you idiot"
You look over to the far side of the cage. Sure enough, the chain that was once there is gone. The man climbs over the side of the cage and drops to the floor.

"Which one?"
"The...one who was on the phone."
